p.text: [Pt 5 am Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 1]
[Div 1 insrt Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 65] s 65 Order to fulfil duty

p.text: The Court may order any person to fulfil any duty in the fulfilment of which the person seeking the order is personally interested.
The Court may, on terms, make an interlocutory order under subsection (1) in any case where it appears to the Court just or convenient so to do.
The powers of the Court under this section are in addition to any other powers of the Court.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 65.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 ss 65, s 65(1) , s 65(2), s 65(3), 69.

As s 65(3) shows, this section confers powers on the court over and above its power to issue mandatory injunctions or mandamus, certiorari or prohibition. The section derives from s 165 of the Common Law Procedure Act 1899 in which the word “duty” clearly meant a duty of a public or quasi-public nature: Benson v Paull (1856) 6 El & Bl 273; 119 ER 865; Norris v Irish Land Co (1857) 8 El & Bl 512; 120 ER 191. Whether a similar approach should be taken to the exercise of the power conferred in s 65(1) is undecided. It might be contended that the effect of s 65(2) and (3) is to confer a power which is exercisable by the court even where the duty in question is not able to be described as either public or quasi-public.

The section enables the court to issue orders akin to mandamus but stripped of the technicalities which restricted their efficacy: see Dickinson v Perrignon [1973] 1 NSWLR 72; P & C Cantarella Pty Ltd v Egg Marketing Board for New South Wales [1973] 2 NSWLR 366; Barham v Stevenson [1975] 1 NSWLR 31; Stevenson v Barham (1977) 136 CLR 190; 12 ALR 175 ; Donges v Ratcliffe [1975] 1 NSWLR 501; McBeatty v Gorman [1976] 2 NSWLR 560. So where this section is applicable, former authorities upon the writ of mandamus are not applicable.

The present section is derived from earlier provisions in ss 165–175 of the Common Law Procedure Act 1899. These provided a simplified procedure that permitted the court to grant relief by way of mandamus, both in proceedings specifically commenced for that purpose and in ordinary proceedings where other relief was claimed. This background assists in understanding what otherwise appears to involve a degree of duplication between ss 65 and 69 of the Supreme Court Act 1970. In the Common Law Procedure Act 1899 provisions, the specific reference to relief by way of mandamus meant that the word "duty" was confined to duties of a public or quasi public nature: Benson v Paull (1856) 6 El & Bl 273; 119 ER 865; Norris v Irish Land Co (1857) 8 El & Bl 512; 120 ER 191. Although it is doubtful that the section was really intended to alter the substantive law (Dickinson v Perrignon [1973] 1 NSWLR 72 at 83 ; Hargrave v Slater (2000) 113 A Crim R 371; [2000] NSWSC 387; BC200003031 at [2] ) it arguably has that effect. The more general wording of the present section, together with s 65(2) , s 65(3) , and the general proposition that statutory grants of judicial power should be construed liberally and not subjected to implied limitations (Owners of Shin Kobe Maru v Empire Shipping Co Inc (1994) 181 CLR 404 at 420–1; 125 ALR 1; BC9404668 ), permit a contention that the section confers a power exercisable even where the duty in question is neither public nor quasi-public. However that may be, the section does provide for a simplified process for the court to issue orders which will have the same compulsive effect as writs of mandamus, but which are available free of the technical and procedural limitations which restricted the grant of mandamus: Dickinson v Perrignon , above, at 83; P & C Cantarella Pty Ltd v Egg Marketing Board for New South Wales [1973] 2 NSWLR 366 at 382 ; Barham v Stevenson [1975] 1 NSWLR 31 ; Stevenson v Barham (1977) 136 CLR 190; 12 ALR 175 ; Donges v Ratcliffe [1975] 1 NSWLR 501 ; McBeatty v Gorman [1976] 2 NSWLR 560 . As to the grounds for the exercise of the power, see [SCA s 69.20] , [SCA s 69.30] , [SCA s 69.45] – [SCA s 69.55] .

Ordinarily, a plaintiff has no standing to bring an action to prevent the violation of a public right if he or she has no interest in the subject matter beyond that of any other member of the public: Day v Pinglen Pty Ltd (1981) 148 CLR 289 at 299; 34 ALR 545 . In order to obtain standing a plaintiff must have a special, in the sense of particular, interest in the subject matter of the litigation. The question of what is a sufficient interest will vary according to the circumstances of individual cases: Australian Conservation Foundation Inc v Commonwealth (1980) 146 CLR 493 at 526; 28 ALR 257 at 267 ; Onus v Alcoa of Australia Ltd (1981) 149 CLR 27; 36 ALR 425 at 431 ; Robinson v Western Australian Museum (1977) 138 CLR 283 at 327; 16 ALR 623 . An applicant may be entitled to an order under this section if the subject of the duty directly affects them, even if they cannot rely on any specific legal right. For example, a deceased's nearest of kin has sufficient interest to obtain an order to compel a coroner to reconsider, according to law, an application for a resumption of a hearing of an inquest into his death: Bilbao v Farquhar [1974] 1 NSWLR 377 (CA). Parents have a common law right to be heard at a coronial enquiry in opposition to any potential adverse finding relating either to themselves or their child: Annetts v McCann [1990] 170 CLR 596. A defendant to litigation in which the plaintiff has been granted legal aid is personally interested in the making of the decision to grant legal aid and therefore has standing to challenge, under this section, the exercise of the discretion to grant legal aid: R v Manchester Legal Aid Committee (1952) 2 QB 413; R v Legal Aid Committee (No 9) [1970] 2 QB 152; Tectran Corp Ltd v Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales (1986) 7 NSWLR 340. A newspaper or broadcaster has standing to challenge the grant of a non publication order preventing the publication of the names of litigants or witnesses: John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd (recs and mgrs apptd) v Local Court of New South Wales (1991) 26 NSWLR 131; 26 ALD 471 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 65.15] Scope and form of order

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 65.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Coroners Act 1980 s 47.

The section applies to conduct that involves a failure to perform a duty, (including a failure to exercise jurisdiction), rather than to a defective performance within the scope of the statutory power: see further [SCA s 69.20] (thus a magistrate's error in relation to the admissibility of evidence cannot found an order under the present section: Hargrave v Slater (2000) 113 A Crim R 371; [2000] NSWSC 387; BC200003031 ). Orders should not ordinarily be made under this section if more specific statutory remedies are available: Re Wigley; Ex parte Mullen [1970] 2 NSWR 297; (1970) 91 WN (NSW) 497 ; Barns v Edwards (1993) 31 NSWLR 714 at 720 . For example, under s 47 of the Coroners Act 1980 the court may direct a coroner to hold an inquest. See further [SCA s 69.20] and [SCA s 69.45] .

The proceedings should ordinarily not name individual defendants who hold the public office or comprise the members of a board. The preferable practice is for proceedings to be brought against the designated public office or the name of the board: Kerr v Cmr of Police [1977] 2 NSWLR 721. See also [SCA s 69.15] .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 65.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 48.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 51.45, 6.12A, rr 6.4.

Proceedings for an order under the present section may be commenced by summons. If the proceedings are assigned to the Court of Appeal (see SCA s 48 and [SCA 48.5] ) the summons must be accompanied by the material required by UCPR r 51.45 . Those requirements include any reasons for decision of the tribunal concerned, and written submissions (to be provided within 28 days). Where the proceedings are assigned to a division of the court, the summons should comply with UCPR rr 6.4 and 6.12A .
The Court may, at any stage of proceedings, by interlocutory or other injunction, restrain any threatened or apprehended breach of contract or other injury.
[subs (1) subst Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
Subsection (1) applies as well in a case where an injury is not actionable unless it causes damage as in other cases.
[subs (2) subst Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
The Court may restrain any threatened or apprehended waste or trespass pursuant to this section—

whether the person against whom the injunction is sought is or is not in possession under any claim of title or otherwise, or (if out of possession) does or does not claim a right to do the act sought to be restrained under any colour of title; and
whether the estate claimed by any party is legal or equitable.
[subs (3) subst Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
The Court may, at any stage of proceedings, on terms, grant an interlocutory injunction in any case in which it appears to the Court to be just or convenient so to do.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.5] Interlocutory injunction where “just or convenient”

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66(4).

Despite the apparent amplitude of s 66(4) it is doubtful that it was intended to do more than reflect, as distinct from effect any significant alteration in, the general non-statutory principles that would otherwise apply to the grant of interlocutory injunctions: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [10], [60], [88]–[92], [105] ; Gaskin v Balls (1879) 13 Ch D 324 at 329 (no injunction to require removal of building erected by predecessor in title); Davis v Hueber (1923) 31 CLR 583 at 597 . In R P Meagher, J D Heydon and M J Leeming, Meagher, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies, 4th ed, LexisNexis, Sydney, 2002 at [21-065]–[21-075], the various cases dealing with the meaning of s 66(4) are considered and the authors agree with Sir Frederick Jordan's Chapters in Equity in NSW, 6th ed, 1945, by F C Stephen, p 149, that the court's powers have not been enlarged. According to this approach the “just or convenient” criterion requires consideration of the settled legal principles on which injunctions may be granted to protect rights and prevent injury or damage: Chief Constable of Kent v V [1983] QB 34; [1982] 3 All ER 36; [1982] 3 WLR 462 ; Beddow v Beddow (1878) 9 Ch D 89 at 93 ; Day v Brownrigg (1886) 10 Ch D 294 at 307; Aslatt v Corp of South Hampton (1880) 16 Ch D 143 at 148 and Harris v Beauchamp [1894] 1 QB 801 . In South Carolina Insurance Co v Assurantie Maatschappij (De Zeven Provincien) NV [1987] AC 24 at 40; [1986] 3 All ER 487 it was said that, subject to the exceptions relating to Mareva (asset preservation) orders and the cases of “inconvenient local forum” (see [s 67.50] behind guide card “Civil Procedure Act”), the court's powers to grant injunctions under the equivalent English provision were limited to situations where a defendant:
invades, or threatens to invade the legal or equitable rights of another; or
behaves, or threatens to behave in an unconscionable manner.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66(4).

The settled interpretation of the “just or convenient” criterion in SCA s 66(4) suggests the general principle justifying the grant of interlocutory relief is that of ensuring the effective exercise of the court’s jurisdiction: Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (1998) 195 CLR 1; 153 ALR 643; BC9801511 at [35] ; American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 406; [1975] 1 All ER 504 per Lord Diplock.

More elaborately expressed, part of the purpose of an interlocutory injunction is to protect a plaintiff against the risk of suffering a loss which any damages ultimately awarded in the proceedings would not provide adequate remedy or compensation. Conversely the apparent justification for a plaintiff’s claim for interlocutory protection must be assessed against a defendant's corresponding entitlement to be protected against any loss resulting from interference with their own asserted, but presently contentious, legal rights.

Faced with this problem of competing disputed rights, the court has to exercise its discretion in the manner best calculated to achieve justice between the parties: Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428 ; Francome v Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd [1984] 2 All ER 408; [1984] 1 WLR 892 at 894 . Fundamental to the exercise of that discretion are:
the nature of the plaintiff's case;
the apparent strength of that case; and
the balance of convenience.

The nature of the plaintiff’s claim is potentially relevant because it is likely to involve issues that invite analogy with established precedent – either because of the particular private interests involved (case Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618; BC6800560 intellectual property) or because of public interest (Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 defamation): see [25.1.47] .

The apparent strength of the case is a material factor because the court must be satisfied the plaintiff has at least a “prima facie case, in the sense that if the evidence remains as it is there is a probability… at the trial… the plaintiff will… be entitled to relief”: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [19], [65]–[71] — approving Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 ; Firth Industries Ltd v Polyglas Engineering Pty Ltd (1975) 132 CLR 489; 6 ALR 212; BC7500043 . The ultimate practical content of this criterion has been debated. (In some instances it had been treated as merely synonymous with a requirement to show there is a “serious question to be tried”. That was the criterion favoured by Lord Diplock in American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 406; [1975] 1 All ER 505 ): see eg Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39 at 49; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113 , per Mason J; Australian Coarse Grain Pool Pty Ltd v Barley Marketing Board of Queensland (No 1) (1982) 46 ALR 398; 57 ALJR 425 , per Gibbs CJ; Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia (1986) 161 CLR 148 at 153; 67 ALR 553; [1986] HCA 58; BC8601376 per Mason ACJ.) The position is now settled that an applicant’s claim must:
apparently invoke a recognised principle: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [20] ; and

have sufficient probability of success to justify the interlocutory orders sought: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [65]–[71] .

The degree of “probability” of success required involves an impressionistic assessment of the apparent “sufficiency” of the plaintiff’s evidence. That assessment will be influenced both by the nature of the proceedings and the nature of the orders sought: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [71] . The practical reality is that a plaintiff must show the existence of a real question to be tried, but that may not, depending on the nature of the issues, be sufficient to establish the necessary degree of “probability” of success. Necessarily the degree of likelihood of success sufficient to discharge that requirement in any particular case is ultimately that which the court thinks sufficient to warrant preservation of the existing state of affairs in order to do justice between the parties: Shercliff v Engadine Acceptance Corp Pty Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 729 ; Magna Alloys & Research Pty Ltd v Coffey [1981] VR 23 ; Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428 ; Construction Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tambel (A'asia) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 274 ; De Mestre v AD Hunter Pty Ltd (1952) 77 WN (NSW) 143 ; R P Meagher, W M C Gummow and J R F Lehane, Equity Doctrines and Remedies, 2nd ed, Butterworths, Sydney, 1984, [2166].

That assessment of the probability of the plaintiff’s success does not involve any forecast of the likely result of the proceedings and does not require an applicant to satisfy the court about the likely ultimate balance of probability: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622-3; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 . Subject to the impressionistic evaluation involved in determining whether there is a sufficient degree of probability in any particular case, a plaintiff generally need only establish a significant prospect of ultimate success in the proceedings: Michael Edgley International Pty Ltd v Ashtons Nominees Pty Ltd (1979) 26 ALR 419 at 421; 38 FLR 135 at 137 ; Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Insurance Brokers Assn of Australia (1977) 16 ALR 161 ; World Series Cricket Pty Ltd v Parish (1977) 16 ALR 181; (1977) ATPR ¶40-040 ; Victorian Egg Marketing Board v Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd (1978) 20 ALR 129 at 145; 33 FLR 294 at 311 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.15] Interlocutory injunctions — the “balance of convenience”

p.text: The expression “balance of convenience” is a shorthand way of alluding to the myriad of factors that can be relevant to the courts consideration of the necessity, utility and fairness of granting interlocutory relief. The nature of the factors to be taken into account, and the relative significance to be accorded to them, will vary according to the particular circumstances of each case. For that reason it would be wrong to think that proper consideration of the balance of convenience can be reduced to a list of preselected matters. Nevertheless the potential width of the matters that can fall to be considered under the balance of convenience include:
the nature of the property or rights in dispute;
the nature of the allegations made;
whether the interlocutory relief sought would overturn, or merely maintain, the status quo;
the effect of the grant or refusal of the injunction on the parties' trade;
the existence of any traditional defence affecting the availability of equitable relief; and
the existence and sufficiency of alternative remedies.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.20] Interlocutory injunction — procedure to obtain

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.8.

Practical considerations relating to applications to obtain interim and interlocutory injunctions are discussed in UCPR [25.1.10]–[25.1.45] . One very important practical consideration is that the court requires an undertaking as to damages before any interlocutory injunction will be given. For the form of the undertaking see UCPR r 25.8 and [25.8.2] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.25] Interlocutory injunction — other statutory provisions

p.text: Where other legislative provisions permit the court to grant interlocutory relief, the relevant considerations must depend upon the terms of the particular statute. However, in the absence of any specific contrary provision, the principles that ordinarily govern the exercise of the courts powers under the present section will apply: Seminara v Ferguson (1993) 16 Fam LR 410; BC9302035 (injunction in aid of a property application under s 38(1)(h) of the De Facto Relationships Act 1984 (NSW)).

The court will not grant an injunction unless the claimant establishes a recognised legal or equitable right and that the infringing act complained of is relevantly unlawful: Sports and General Press Agency Ltd v Our Dogs Publishing Co Ltd [1917] 2 KB 125 ; Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia v JW Alexander Ltd (1918) 25 CLR 434 at 464; 24 ALR 341 . The absence of a cause of action against the party sought to be restrained will not always disentitle a plaintiff from obtaining relief — at least where the application is based upon the need to preserve the subject matter of the litigation: eg Williams v Marac Australia Ltd (1985) 5 NSWLR 529; 3 BPR 9638 (injunction against the Registrar General) and see also The Rena K [1979] QB 377 at 407; [1979] 1 All ER 397 ; Construction Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tambel (A'asia) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 274 (Mareva, asset preservation, order). It follows that an injunction cannot properly be granted where the case involves mere inconvenience rather than legal injury or loss: Day v Brownrigg (1886) 10 Ch D 294. Moreover, an injunction ought not be granted if the alleged infringement is merely trivial (Llandudno Urban District Council v Woods [1899] 2 Ch 705 ; Behrens v Richards [1905] 2 Ch 614 ); or where the scope of the injunction claimed would interfere with the exercise of third party rights (Earl of Harrington v Derby Corp [1905] 1 Ch 205 at 220–1 ); or where a compensatory award of damages would constitute an effective and adequate remedy (London & Blackwell Railway Co v Cross (1885) 31 Ch D 354 per Lindley LJ at 369; see Prosperity Ltd v Lloyds Bank Ltd (1923) 39 TLR 372 ; cf Walter v Ashton [1902] 2 Ch 282 at 293 (inchoate rights of property will be protected: Zobel v Croudace (1898) 20 LR (NSW) 28); R v MacFarlane; Ex parte O'Flanagan (1923) 32 CLR 518 at 540–1; 29 ALR 353 (injunction to protect personal liberty)); or where the claimant has the practical ability to prevent further actionable conduct: Elliman, Sons & Co Ltd v Carrington & Son Ltd [1901] 2 Ch 275 at 279 (possible contractual stipulation governing future conduct). General rules as to when an injunction is to be granted are found in R P Meagher, J D Heydon and M J Leeming, Meagher, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies, 4th ed, LexisNexis, Sydney, 2002 at Ch 21; F Jordan's Chapters in Equity in NSW, 6th ed, 1945, p 148 and following.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 135.

Interlocutory orders concerning matters of practice and procedure are incidental to the effective exercise of the court's jurisdiction and the court retains complete authority over the manner of its exercise: EI Du Pont de Nemours & Co v Cmr of Patents (1987) 16 FCR 423; 83 ALR 499 (consent order for discovery). In many instances orders of that kind are intended to operate only "until further order" or final judgment. Conditions of this kind will often be express, or necessarily implied, in the terms of the relevant order and they necessarily carry with them the right to apply for a further order. Consequently, the court has complete power to vary interlocutory orders, including injunctions, to take account of changed circumstances: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 at 766 ; Wilkshire v Commonwealth (1976) 9 ALR 325 at 366 ; Philip Morris Inc v Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd (1980) 148 CLR 457; 31 ALR 232 at 253. There is a less extensive power in relation to injunctions that have been made in the form of final orders in the proceedings. But even then, if the law or circumstances have materially altered since the final order was made, the court may suspend further operation of the order under s 135 of the CPA: Permewan Wright Consolidated Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW); Ex rel Franklins Stores Pty Ltd (1978) 35 NSWLR 365 (a decision based upon the former SCR r 42.12). See also Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation v Perry (1988) 92 FLR 182 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.40] The effect of consenting to an interlocutory injunction

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66(4), s 68.

heading.title: The effect of consenting to an interlocutory injunction

p.text: It seems there may be cases where consent to the grant of an interlocutory injunction under s 66(4) may preclude the consenting party from contending at the hearing that there was no jurisdiction to grant final relief, under s 68 , the claim for which relief the interlocutory injunction was ancillary: Millstream Pty Ltd v Schultz [1980] 1 NSWLR 547 at 552–3 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.45] Relevant date of applicable law

p.text: When considering the grant of an injunction the court applies the law at the date when the question falls to be determined: Application des Gaz SA v Falks Veritas Ltd [1974] Ch 381; [1974] 3 All ER 51 ; Trade Practices Commission v Legion Cabs (Trading) Co-op Society Ltd (1978) 35 FLR 372; 4 TPC 276 .

Consistent with the general principles referred to in [SCA s 66.10] and [SCA s 66.15] the existence of an effective undertaking in relation to the allegedly infringing conduct may both materially influence, and justify, the court in refusing to make a a compulsive order against the allegedly infringing party. Undertakings are of two types: undertakings between the parties (which have the force of a mere agreement between the parties) and undertakings to the court (which can, in practical terms, be enforced in substantially the same way as an injunction: Biba Ltd v Stratford Investments Ltd [1973] Ch 281 at 287; [1972] 3 All ER 1041 ; compare Spindler v Balog (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 391 (undertaking to pay money); Cutler v Wandsworth Stadium Ltd [1945] 1 All ER 103 ). If an undertaking is offered an interlocutory stage of the proceedings, the court may accept any undertaking that is reasonably related to the orderly management and proper disposal of the proceedings: Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 148 CLR 150; 37 ALR 66; BC8100114 ; Electrical Trades Union of Australia v Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia (1982) 40 ALR 173; 56 FLR 430 . But the court should not accept any final undertaking unless it is satisfied that it has the power, and that it would otherwise be appropriate, to make an order in substantially the same terms: see Thomson's case, above, at ALR 76.

The court can release a party from an undertaking to the same extent that it can vary or discharge any interlocutory order or injunction: Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170 at 177–8; 35 ALR 625 at 629–30 ; Chanel Ltd v FW Woolworth & Co Ltd [1981] 1 All ER 745; [1981] 1 WLR 485 ; Lonrho Plc v Fayed (No 4) [1994] QB 775 at 781; [1994] 1 All ER 870 . The discretionary factors relevant to the exercise of the court's powers to vary interlocutory orders also apply to a party's application to be released from an interlocutory undertaking. One of those factors is the need to take account of the desirability of avoiding unnecessary applications for interlocutory orders: see [25.1.65] , [25.1.80] . Accordingly, it will usually be necessary for an applicant to show some material change in circumstances in order to justify the release of an order or undertaking: see [SCA s 66.35] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.60] Variation of consent orders and undertakings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.

heading.title: Variation of consent orders and undertakings

p.text: There is some uncertainty as to whether even a material change in circumstances justifies the exercise of the discretion to vary an order, or release an undertaking, that was the result of a contractual arrangement between the parties: RD Werner & Co Inc v Bailey Aluminium Products Pty Ltd (1988) 18 FCR 389; 80 ALR 134 ; Purcell v FC Trigell Ltd [1971] 1 QB 358; [1970] 3 All ER 671 . The argument occasioning the uncertainty is that no variation should be permitted unless there are grounds to impugn the underlying contract between the parties: Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 198 ; Fylas Pty Ltd v Vynal Pty Ltd [1992] 2 Qd R 593 ; Industrial Rollformers Pty Ltd v Ingersoll-Rand (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) [2001] NSWCA 455; BC200107867 . Because of that uncertainty, the courts are reluctant to characterise consent orders as probative of a contractual agreement between the parties: Siebe Gorman & Co Ltd v Pneupac Ltd [1982] 1 All ER 377; [1982] 1 WLR 185 ; see also [36.16.40] and [SCA s 101.90] . Furthermore, in many cases the practical significance of the contractual obligation can be reduced by resort to specific additional powers, such as the power to extend time (see UCPR r 1.12 ) or the power to set aside judgments entered following non-compliance with self-executing orders: see [36.16.75] .

There are some judicial observations to the effect that releasing a party from a contractual undertaking to pay damages for merely discharges the obligation to the court and does not affect the person’s potential contractual liability: Purcell v FC Trigell Ltd , above, at QB 367; All ER 677; Thwaite v Thwaite [1982] Fam 1 at 9 . That proposition may be accepted in relation to an entitlement to damages resulting from breaches of the undertaking that occurred before any release or variation. But the court's power to release an undertaking is impliedly within the relevant contractual contemplation of the parties and its exercise will ordinarily be inconsistent with the original undertaking having any future contractual operation.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 66.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66(4).

The court may make orders designed either to preserve property, or the (contested) rights of the parties, pending an appeal. That power may be attributed either to s 66(4) or to the court's incidental or inherent jurisdiction: see [51.44.5] and [51.44.30] .
The general principles relating to the form and contents of injunctions are discussed in [25.2.15] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.75] Injunction to restrain the commission of a criminal offence

heading.title: Injunction to restrain the commission of a criminal offence

p.text: A defendant’s unlawful conduct may consitute both a criminal offence and an actionable wrong which gives rise to an entitlement to an injunction in accordance with general equitable principles, irrespective of any question of criminality. In such a case the court retains its general equitable jurisdiction, and an individual plaintiff may sue for an injunction, unless statutory provisions evidence a clear intention that criminal proceedings provide the exclusive sanction: Walsh v Alexander (1913) 16 CLR 293; 13 SR (NSW) 566 ; Webster v Bread Carters' Union of New South Wales (1930) 30 SR (NSW) 267 ; Stevens v Chown; Stevens v Clark [1901] 1 Ch 894 ; Wolverhampton New Waterworks Co v Hawkesford (1859) 6 CBNS 336 at 356; 141 ER 486 at 495. Similarly, it may be apparent that a statutory prohibition is intended to confer a private right analogous to the rights that equity would regard as enforceable by injunction: eg, property rights. In such cases, an injunction will be potentially available to an individual litigant unless the statutory sanction is intended to be exclusive: Stevens v Chown , above; Dowse v Wynyard Holdings Ltd [1962] NSWR 252 (injunction to restrain interference with rights of a statutory licensee); Duchess of Argyll v Duke of Argyll [1967] Ch 302 (injunction to restrain publication of evidence in matrimonial proceedings); Bradley v Commonwealth (1973) 128 CLR 557; 1 ALR 241 (injunction to restrain interference with delivery of postal services).

Alternatively, an individual plaintiff will be entitled to seek injunctive relief where the conduct involves an element of special damage to the plaintiff: Boyce v Paddington Borough Council [1903] 1 Ch 109 ; Kathleen Investments (Aust) Ltd v Australian Atomic Energy Commission (1977) 139 CLR 117; 16 ALR 535 (declaration as to the power of a statutory authority to acquire shares in a corporation); Onus v Alcoa of Australia Ltd (1981) 149 CLR 27 at 36; 36 ALR 425 (injunction to restrain building activities on protected land); John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Doe (1995) 37 NSWLR 81 (injunction to restrain illegal publication that would also constitute contempt — by prejudicing a person’s right to a fair trial pending criminal proceedings).

Apart from instances of criminal conduct that are also privately actionable, an injunction will lie to restrain the commission of a criminal offence. But enforcement of the criminal law by civil injunction at the suit of a private litigant is an exceptional and narrowly confined jurisdiction: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [47] ff per Gleeson CJ; Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113 (Crimes Act 1914 (Cth) contravention insufficient to justify injunction — injunction granted to protect copyright); Pillay (t/as West Corp Mortgage Market) v Nine Network Australia Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 983; BC200206258 (TV program based on contravention of the Listening Devices Act 1984 — injunction refused). The categories of exceptional case where injunction may issue are those where the party sought to be restrained has evinced a clear intention to continue to flout the law or where the processes of the criminal law and the penalties involved have failed to deter the defendant from continuing to act in breach of the law: Stoke-on-Trent City Council v B and Q (Retail) Ltd [1984] AC 754 ; Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39 at 49; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113 ; Institute of Patent Agents v Lockwood [1894] AC 347 at 361 ; Gouriet v Union of Post Office Workers [1978] AC 435 at 481 ; Attorney-General (Qld); Ex rel Kerr v T (1983) 46 ALR 275 at 277; 57 ALJR 285 ; Ramsey v Aberfoyle Manufacturing Co (Aust) Pty Ltd (1935) 54 CLR 230; 9 ALJR 350 ; Cooney v Ku-ring-gai Municipal Council (1963) 114 CLR 582; [1964] ALR 98 ; Peek v New South Wales Egg Corp (1986) 6 NSWLR 1 ; Zimitat v Douglas [1979] Qd R 454 ; Corvisy v Corvisy [1982] 2 NSWLR 557 ; Parry v Crooks (1981) 27 SASR 1 . Compare Attorney-General (Cth) v Legal Research Pty Ltd [1993] 2 Qd R 472 (mandatory injunction granted to enforce compliance with the statutory obligation).

Ordinarily the Attorney-General is the appropriate plaintiff in proceedings for an injunction to restrain the commission of a criminal offence: Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39 at 49; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113 ; Australian Conservation Foundation Inc v Commonwealth (1980) 146 CLR 493; 28 ALR 257 ; Gouriet v Union of Post Office Workers [1978] AC 435 ; John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Doe (1995) 37 NSWLR 81 ; Phillips v New South Wales Fish Marketing Authority [1970] 1 NSWR 725 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.80] Injunction to restrain criminal proceedings

p.text: If there is power to restrain the institution of criminal proceedings, it could only be appropriately exercised in the most exceptional of cases: Jarrett v Seymour (1993) 46 FCR 521; 119 ALR 10 at 47 . As to the circumstances where the court might use its inherent jurisdiction to stay criminal proceedings see [s 67.15] - [s 67.20] , [SCA s 23.20] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 66.85] Injunction to restrain publication of defamatory material

heading.title: Injunction to restrain publication of defamatory material

p.text: The Court may, at any stage of proceedings, on terms, appoint a receiver by interlocutory order in any case in which it appears to the Court to be just or convenient so to do.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 67.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66, s 67.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1323(1)(h).
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 29.

The words just or convenient appear in both s 66 and in the present section. In [SCA s 66.1] the question was canvassed as to whether the words operate to confer a general discretion upon the court. The comments there made would seem to apply equally to s 67 . However, in Parker v Camden London Borough Council [1986] 1 Ch 162 it was said that the jurisdiction conferred under the equivalent provision in s 37 of the Supreme Court Act 1981 (UK), was “quite general and, in terms, unlimited”. As to the general power to appoint receivers see Halsbury's Laws of England , 4th ed, Butterworths, London, Vol 39, para 801 and following, and Vol 17, para 574 and following (equitable execution). Particular powers of appointment of receivers are given, for example, in s 1323(1)(h) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth). Generally, an applicant must show: (1) a right which will be protected or enforced by the appointment; and (2) that no other available remedy is adequate for that purpose. The appointment will not be made as a means of establishing a regime for the administration of the affairs of a company where doing so might prejudice the interests of creditors: Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd (1990) 1 ACSR 445. In Bastion v Gideon Investments (2000) 35 ACSR 466; 18 ACLC 854 , Austin J appointed as receiver manager a liquidator of a company in order that the liquidator avoid conflicts which may arise between duties owed as a liquidator and duties owed as trustee to investors of the company. See also the annotations to Pt 29 of the Supreme Court Rules.

It is inappropriate for the power to appoint a receiver to be exercised in respect of the undertaking or assets of a body which is exercising powers of management, regulation or control conferred by statute: Parker v Camden London Borough Council [1986] 1 Ch 162; Gardner v London Chatham and Dover Railway Co (No 1) (1867) LR 2 Ch App 201 at 212; Marshall v South Staffordshire Tramways Co [1895] 2 Ch 36.

It is just or convenient to appoint a receiver to the rents of a tenanted property where the lessor persistently declines to comply with covenants to keep the demised property in repair: Hart v Emelkirk Ltd [1983] 3 All ER 15; [1983] 1 WLR 1289; Clayope Properties Ltd v Evans (1986) 279 EG 855.

Upon the dissolution of a partnership or in proceedings for the taking of partnership accounts it is common for a receiver to be appointed. Indeed, it has been said that a receiver will be appointed practically as of course: Tate v Barry (1928) 28 SR (NSW) 380 at 383 . However, the court retains a discretion and may refuse to make an appointment if it is of the view that the receivership could cause serious loss or hardship: eg, Fitz-Gibbon v Khoury (NSWSC, Powell J, 1 March 1985, unreported, BC8500947). In the case of a professional partnership, the principal asset of which will often be goodwill, it has been said that the appointment of a receiver will often be undesirable: Sobell v Boston [1975] 1 WLR 1587.

The court may appoint a receiver by way of equitable execution: Bourne v Colodense [1985] ICR 291; [1985] IRLR 339 (right to claim indemnity); Maclaine Watson & Co Ltd v International Tin Council [1988] 1 Ch 1; [1987] 3 All ER 787; [1987] 3 WLR 508 . The concept of “equitable execution” involves the realisation of property either without the usual formalities of execution, or where the particular property interest is not readily amenable to possession and realisation as a recognised property interest at law: DM & BP Wiskich Pty Ltd v Saadi (NSWSC, Bryson J, 16 February 1996, unreported, BC9600188) (legal remedies ineffectual, receiver appointed on undertaking from the judgment creditor to meet the receiver's charges). For example, a receiver can be appointed in relation to future payments that are neither actually due, nor accrued, at the time of the appointment: Soinco Saci & Eural KFT v Novokuznetsk Aluminium Plant Base Metal Trading Ltd [1998] QB 406; [1997] 3 All ER 523; [1998] 2 WLR 334; [1997] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 330 . The power to appoint receivers in such a situation derives from the court’s inherent jurisdiction: Corporate Affairs Commission v Smithson [1984] 3 NSWLR 547 at 552; (1984) 9 ACLR 371; (1985) 3 ACLC 230 ; and perhaps also from the terms of SCA s 67: Hall v Foster [2012] NSWSC 974; BC201207045 at [18]–[19] (s 67 seen as conferring a separate power).

There is no occasion to appoint a receiver, by way of equitable execution, if the judgment creditor has other reasonably effective means of enforcing the judgment debt: Hall v Foster [2012] NSWSC 974; BC201207045 at [19]–[21] (registered mortgagee with enforceable power of sale).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 68] s 68 Damages in case for equitable relief

leg:heading.title: Damages in case for equitable relief

p.text: Where the Court has power—
to grant an injunction against the breach of any covenant, contract or agreement, or against the commission or continuance of any wrongful act; or
to order the specific performance of any covenant, contract or agreement,
the Court may award damages to the party injured either in addition to or in substitution for the injunction or specific performance.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 68.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 68(b).

Lord Cairns Act 1858 gave the Equity Court power to award damages. This section restates that power. It does not alter the general principles that govern the award of damages for common law and equitable causes of action. The section does not, eg, confer a general discretion to award damages as a substitute for injunctive relief. Accordingly, a plaintiff who has a cause of action at law will be awarded damages in accordance with common law principles. Similarly, a plaintiff whose cause of action is equitable only, will be entitled to damages in accordance with settled equitable principles: ASA Constructions Pty Ltd v Iwanov [1975] 1 NSWLR 512. In a case of continuing actionable nuisance an injunction will generally be granted: Shelfer v City of London Electric Lighting Co [1895] 1 Ch 287; Kennaway v Thompson [1980] 3 All ER 329. In proceedings for specific performance, there is only power to award damages under s 68(b) if, when the proceedings were commenced, the facts were such that the court could then, subject, perhaps, only to discretionary defences, have properly ordered specific performance: Millstream Pty Ltd v Schultz [1980] 1 NSWLR 547 at 552; Mills v Ruthol Pty Ltd (2004) 61 NSWLR 1; [2004] NSWSC 547; BC200403824 at [61] . If the circumstances change after the commencement of the proceedings so that specific performance or a final injunction becomes impossible or would be refused on discretionary grounds, the court’s power to award damages under s 68 is not lost: Mills v Ruthol Pty Ltd, above, at [61] . The section cannot be used by a court to grant damages for breach of observance of a statute where the court has refused a claim for injunctive relief: Wentworth v Woollahra Municipal Council (1982) 149 CLR 672; 42 ALR 69 . The general position under the present section is that damages can be awarded where: (1) the injury to the plaintiff's rights is small; (2) it is capable of being estimated in money; (3) the plaintiff is adequately compensated by a small money payment; (4) to grant an injunction would be oppressive to the defendant: Shelfer v City of London Electric Lighting Co, above, Kennaway v Thompson, above.

Consistent with those principles, damages have been awarded in cases involving breaches of restrictive building covenants. It has been held that the appropriate amount could be assessed by having regard to the amount that the plaintiff might reasonably have demanded for relaxing the covenant: Jaggard v Sawyer [1995] 1 WLR 269, discussed in (1995) 14 CJQ 16 and (1995) 69 ALJ 482.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 68.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 35 r 3.

The choice of the appropriate date of assessment depends upon what is just as between the parties: Madden v Kevereski [1983] 1 NSWLR 305. Common law damages in contract are assessed at the date of breach. Damages under the present section may be assessed at the date of judgment, but there is no general rule requiring assessment at that date rather than at the date of accrual of the cause of action: Wroth v Tyler [1974] Ch 30 ; ASA Constructions Pty Ltd v Iwanov [1975] 1 NSWLR 512. Where damages are payable in relation to a past breach that was relied upon in support of a claim for specific performance, damages may be appropriately assessed as at the date of the breach: ASA Constructions Pty Ltd v Iwanov, above. But where damages under s 68 are a substitute for specific performance then the appropriate date of assessment will ordinarily be when the plaintiff’s intention or ability to recover only damages was finally and unequivocally made clear: Mills v Ruthol Pty Ltd (2004) 61 NSWLR 1; [2004] NSWSC 547; BC200403824 (contract for sale of land — damages not assessed until Court of Appeal made an order for specific performance in favour of the later option holder); Madden v Kevereski, above (where there was a discretionary refusal of specific performance and damages were assessed at the date of judgment). If damages are claimed in relation to a continuing cause of action or in relation to repeated breaches of a recurring or continuing obligation, they should be assessed as at the date of the assessment: Pt 35 r 3 of the Rules.

It is not necessary to make a specific claim to recover damages under this section but the form of the plaintiff's claim should sufficiently indicate whether it is confined to damages for past injury at common law or also relates to the risk of continuing or future injury: Jaggard v Sawyer [1995] 1 WLR 269 at 285.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 69] s 69 Proceedings in lieu of writs

p.text: Where formerly—
the Court had jurisdiction to grant any relief or remedy or do any other thing by way of writ, whether of prohibition, mandamus, certiorari or of any other description; or

in any proceedings in the Court for any relief or remedy any writ might have issued out of the Court for the purpose of the commencement or conduct of the proceedings, or otherwise in relation to the proceedings, whether the writ might have issued pursuant to any rule or order of the Court or of course,
then, after the commencement of this Act—
the Court shall continue to have jurisdiction to grant that relief or remedy or to do that thing; but
shall not issue any such writ; and
shall grant that relief or remedy or do that thing by way of judgment or order under this Act and the rules; and
proceedings for that relief or remedy or for the doing of that thing shall be in accordance with this Act and the rules.
Subject to the rules, this section does not apply to—
the writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum;
any writ of execution for the enforcement of a judgment or order of the Court; or
any writ in aid of any such writ of execution.

It is declared that the jurisdiction of the Court to grant any relief or remedy in the nature of a writ of certiorari includes jurisdiction to quash the ultimate determination of a court or tribunal in any proceedings if that determination has been made on the basis of an error of law that appears on the face of the record of the proceedings.
[subs (3) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
For the purposes of subsection (3) , the face of the record includes the reasons expressed by the court or tribunal for its ultimate determination.
[subs (4) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

Subsections (3) and (4) do not affect the operation of any legislative provision to the extent to which the provision is, according to common law principles and disregarding those subsections, effective to prevent the Court from exercising its powers to quash or otherwise review a decision.
[subs (5) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 69.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 http://www.lexisnexis.com/au/legal/search/run RemoteLink.do?bct=A&RISB=21_T16394731407&homeCsi=285211&A=0.7817232401422045& urlEnc=ISO-8859-1&&dpsi=05CC&remotekey1=REFPTID&refpt=UCPN.UCPR.UCPRN05.R51 -45&service=DOC-ID&origdpsi=05CC, r 51.45, 6.12A, http://www.lexisnexis.com/au/legal/search/ runRemoteLink.do?bct=A&risb=21_T16394731407&homeCsi=285211&A=0.7817232401422045 &urlEnc=ISO-8859-1&&dpsi=05CC&remotekey1=REFPTID&reft=UCPN.UCPR.UCPRN05.R6- 4&service=DOC-ID&origdpsi=05CC, rr 6.4, r 6.4(1)(b1).

A person may have sufficient standing to commence, and obtain relief in, proceedings under the present section even if they cannot establish a specific legal right, or that the apprehended exercise of the contentious power will necessarily affect them adversely: Maksimovic v Walsh [1983] 2 NSWLR 656 (person apprehending misuse of coroner’s power).

Proceedings under this section only lie where the relevant duty is conferred upon an office holder or designated person. Proceedings do not lie where the relevant duty is really one owed by a person who represents the Crown. As to the distinction see Re Minister for Education [1961] NSWR 989; [1962] SR (NSW) 220; (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 1000 ; R v Secretary of State for War [1891] 2 QB 326 ; R v Lords Cmrs of the Treasury (1872) LR 7 QB 387 and cf Padfield v Minister of Agriculture [1968] AC 997; [1968] 1 All ER 694; [1968] 2 WLR 924 .
Proceedings under this section must be commenced by summons: UCPR r 6.4(1)(b1) .

If the proceedings are assigned to the Court of Appeal, the summons must be accompanied by the material required by, and complying with, UCPR http://www.lexisnexis.com/au/legal/search/run RemoteLink.do?bct=A&RISB=21_T16394731407&homeCsi=285211&A=0.7817232401422045& urlEnc=ISO-8859-1&&dpsi=05CC&remotekey1=REFPTID&refpt=UCPN.UCPR.UCPRN05.R51 -45&service=DOC-ID&origdpsi=05CC r 51.45 . If the proceedings are assigned to a Division of the Court, the summons should comply with UCPR http://www.lexisnexis.com/au/legal/search/ runRemoteLink.do?bct=A&risb=21_T16394731407&homeCsi=285211&A=0.7817232401422045 &urlEnc=ISO-8859-1&&dpsi=05CC&remotekey1=REFPTID&reft=UCPN.UCPR.UCPRN05.R6- 4&service=DOC-ID&origdpsi=05CC rr 6.4 & 6.12A and not only contain a statement setting out “briefly but specifically” the grounds relied on in support of the claim but also annex a copy of the reasons for decision: see Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 78 NSWLR 499; 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 at [8] and [133] ; White v Grogan [1972] 2 NSWLR 347 .

Defendants who are office holders in the inferior court or tribunal should be described by their official title, and not their personal name: Kerr v Cmr of Police [1977] 2 NSWLR 721 ; cf Horne v Locke [1978] 2 NSWLR 88 and Hamblin v Duffy (No 2) (1981) 37 ALR 297 at 308; 55 FLR 228 at 243–4 . Where an office holder dies after proceedings have been commenced, the court may grant orders against their successor: see, eg, Re Toohey; Ex parte Meneling Station Pty Ltd (1982) 158 CLR 327; 44 ALR 63 at 73; 57 ALJR 59; BC8200137 .

Where the proceedings of a court or tribunal are the subject of an application under this section, it is usually appropriate for the court or tribunal merely to submit to such order as the court may make: Commonwealth v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (1995) 63 FCR 74; 133 ALR 629 . This is because active participation in the proceedings risks endangering the impartiality that would be required in any proceedings that would take place following the grant of relief under this section. However, in appropriate cases it may be proper, and sometimes desirable, for limited submissions to be made concerning the powers and procedures of the court or tribunal in question: R v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal; Ex parte Hardiman (1980) 144 CLR 13 at 35; 29 ALR 289 at 305 ; Fagan v Crimes Compensation Tribunal (1982) 150 CLR 666; 42 ALR 511 ; Holloway v Chairperson of the Residential Tribunal (2001) 51 NSWLR 716 at 726–8; [2001] NSWCA 209; BC200103672 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 69.20] Limitation to judicial functions/jurisdictional error (pre-1996 amendments)

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 69.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 65.

heading.title: Limitation to judicial functions/jurisdictional error (pre-1996 amendments)

p.text: Prior to its amendment in 1996, the section had been held not to alter the jurisdiction of the court to grant relief in the nature of mandamus, certiorari or prohibition, or the principles governing the exercise of that jurisdiction: Dickinson v Perrignon [1973] 1 NSWLR 72 per Street CJ in Eq. See also [SCA s 65.5] ; P & C Cantarella Pty Ltd v Egg Marketing Board (NSW) [1973] 2 NSWLR 366 at 382 ; Hargrave v Slater (2000) 113 A Crim R 371; [2000] NSWSC 387; BC200003031 .

Orders in the nature of prerogative relief (mandamus, certiorari and prohibition) are generally available only in relation to the exercise of judicial functions: R v Wright; Ex parte Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia (1955) 93 CLR 528 at 541; [1955] ALR 654 . This limitation generated a “long standing controversy”: Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1 at 83; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; as to whether orders in the nature of the prerogative writs could be granted in respect of committal proceedings (which are conventionally characterised as involving administrative or executive functions). In Re Blackett; Ex parte Cousens (1946) 47 SR (NSW) 145; 63 WN (NSW) 228 it had been held that the writs would not lie: see also Re Cooper; Ex parte Lyndon (1957) 57 SR (NSW) 626 at 629, 680; Re McMurray; Ex parte Donald (1969) 89 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 462 at 466 . That decision was followed in Re Evans; Ex parte Coffey [1971] 1 NSWLR 434 and in Connor v Sankey [1976] 2 NSWLR 570; (1976) 21 ALR 317 ; BC7800068 , the Court of Appeal, by majority, refused to depart from the earlier decision. In Sankey v Whitlam , above, the High Court held that declaratory relief was available in relation to committal proceedings: see [SCA s 69.30] ; but did not overrule Ex parte Cousens , above. Subsequently, Ex parte Cousens , above, was consistently followed in a number of cases at first instance: Green v Jones [1979] 2 NSWLR 812; (1979) 39 FLR 428 ; Spautz v Williams [1983] 2 NSWLR 506; Wentworth v Rogers [1983] 3 NSWLR 161.

However, orders in the nature of mandamus and certiorari may be made where a magistrate has made a jurisdictional error: Wade v Burns (1966) 115 CLR 537 at 555; [1966] ALR 1137 ; Re McMurray; Ex parte Donald , above, at 468–9; Sankey v Whitlam [1977] 1 NSWLR 333 at 346; (1977) 21 ALR 457; BC7800068 ; Wentworth v Rogers [1984] 2 NSWLR 422; Carlin v Thawat Chidkunthod (1985) 4 NSWLR 182.

The concept of “jurisdictional error”, and in particular the distinction between “jurisdictional and non jurisdictional error” is notoriously difficult to apply and not subject to rigid classification: Coal and Allied Operations Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission (2000) 203 CLR 194 at 227; 174 ALR 585; [2000] HCA 47; BC200005034 ; Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of NSW (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [56], [64], [66] and [72]–[73]. In its most readily described occurrences, jurisdictional error may involve either a failure to appreciate the proper statutory criteria, or the purported exercise of power in disregard of the limitations on the scope of the statutory authority: Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of NSW (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [72] (misunderstanding of statutory power and failure to apply the rules of evidence — jurisdictional error); Craig v South Australia (1995) 184 CLR 163; 131 ALR 595; [1995] HCA 58; BC9506437 (certiorari); R v Judges of the Federal Court of Australia; Ex parte Pilkington ACI (Operations) Pty Ltd (1978) 142 CLR 113; 23 ALR 69 (prohibition); Saffron v DPP (1989) 16 NSWLR 397 at 419 ; Re Kearsley Shire Council; Ex parte Hebburn Ltd (1947) 47 SR (NSW) 416 at 420 .

If the jurisdiction of a court or tribunal is in fact limited, no statutory provision can preclude the exercise of the supervisory jurisdiction of a State Supreme Court to set aside decisions that have been affected by jurisdictional error: Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of NSW (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [56], [100].

heading.title: Non jurisdictional error / error on the face of the record:

p.text: An error made within jurisdiction (and not on the face of the record — see [SCA s 69.25] ), for example, an error in relation to the admissibility of evidence, cannot be the subject of an application for orders under either this section or s 65 : Hargrave v Slater (2000) 113 A Crim R 371; [2000] NSWSC 387; BC200003031 (for example, an error in relation to the admissibility of evidence); Potier v DPP (2001) 123 A Crim R 176; [2001] NSWSC 514; BC200104023 (refusal to permit cross-examination at committal proceedings). But the scope of the limitation to errors of law “on the face of the record” depends on the proper identification of what constitutes the “record”. Under the general law that was a matter of some controversy, especially in relation to the reasons for decision of a court or tribunal: see Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of NSW (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [81]–[85].

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 69.25] Jurisdiction extended to patent errors of law

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 69.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 section, Section 69(3)–(5), s 69(5).
(NSW) Justices Act 1902 s 146.

heading.title: Jurisdiction extended to patent errors of law

p.text: Section 69(3)–(5) , which were amended in 1996, extended the court’s jurisdiction, subject to any other contrary legislative provision, to all cases involving error of law on the face of the record: see s 69(5) and Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Farley (2001) 51 NSWLR 494; [2001] NSWSC 326; BC200101937 . Furthermore, the “record” was deemed to include any reasons for decision — so as to overcome the effect of the decision in Craig v South Australia (1995) 184 CLR 163; 131 ALR 595; [1995] HCA 58; BC9506437 . Thus, after the March 1999 repeal of s 146 of the Justices Act 1902: Kopuz v District Court of New South Wales (1992) 28 NSWLR 232 ; those subsections operated to permit orders to be made under the present section in relation to patent errors of law in Local Court proceedings: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Farley (2001) 51 NSWLR 494; [2001] NSWSC 326; BC200101937 .

The extended jurisdiction conferred by the inclusion of a court or tribunal’s reasons for decision in the “record” does not preclude the effective operation of statutory provisions providing for the finality of those decisions — except to the extent that the relevant error is properly characterised as “jurisdictional”: Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of NSW (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [56], [100].
Legislation cited in [SCA s 69.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75.

Declaratory relief under s 75 is available in relation to committal proceedings, even though special circumstances will have to be shown before the making of a declaration will be appropriate: Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1 at 25–6, 81–2; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Imperial Tobacco Ltd v A-G [1981] AC 718; (1981) 21 ALR 505 ; Gorman v Fitzpatrick (1985) 4 NSWLR 286; Moss v Brown [1979] 1 NSWLR 114 at 132; Crouch v Commonwealth (1948) 77 CLR 339 at 348; [1949] ALR 114 . Indeed, many cases affirm the existence of the jurisdiction although the occasions of its exercise are relatively few: Bacon v Rose [1972] 2 NSWLR 793 (unsuccessful allegation that committal proceedings invalidly commenced — declaration refused); Willesee v Willesee [1974] 2 NSWLR 275 (statutory right to a hearing in closed court — declaration granted); Acs v Anderson [1974] 2 NSWLR 482; affirmed Acs v Anderson [1975] 1 NSWLR 212 (waiver of privilege — declaration refused); Csidei v Anderson [1977] 1 NSWLR 747 (whether an information disclosed an offence known to the law — declaration refused); Bourke v Hamilton [1977] 1 NSWLR 470 (whether prima facie case made out — declaration refused); Gorman v Fitzpatrick (1985) 4 NSWLR 286 (whether prima facie case made out –— relief granted); Spautz v Williams [1983] 2 NSWLR 506 (whether defendant properly discharged — declaration refused); Perry v Nash (1980) 32 ALR 177; 47 FLR 210 (admissibility of evidence — declaration refused); Conwell v Tapfield [1981] 1 NSWLR 595 (admissibility of transcript of tape recording — declaration granted).

In Maksimovic v Walsh [1983] 2 NSWLR 656 (on appeal Attorney-General (NSW) v Maksimovich (1985) 4 NSWLR 300; 22 A Crim R 392), a declaration was made under this section that a coroner had no jurisdiction on the termination of a coronial inquiry to suggest that a named person had committed an indictable offence: see also Bilbao v Farquhar [1978] 1 NSWLR 528 at 535; Mirror Newspapers Ltd v Waller (1985) 1 NSWLR 1.

Ordinarily, the prerogative writs do not lie against a superior court: R v Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration; Ex parte Amalgamated Engineering Union (1953) 89 CLR 636; [1953] ALR 821; BC5300790 ; Re Myers; Ex parte Groot (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 496. Consistent with that proposition:

a judge of the Supreme Court has no power to direct an order in the nature of prohibition to, or to grant an injunction against, another judge of the court: Fleet v Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals NSW [2008] NSWCA 227; BC200808340 at [36] ; Bird v Free, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education & Training (1994) 35 ALD 552; 126 ALR 475; BC9400182 ; Barton v Walker [1979] 2 NSWLR 740 (the refusal of a judge to disqualify him or herself for alleged bias can be raised on an appeal against the final judgment in the proceedings, but it cannot be the subject of a direct appeal or otherwise challenged by a claim for a declaration or prerogative orders); but see Rajski v Wood (1989) 18 NSWLR 512 at 518 ; Australian National Industries Ltd v Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) (1992) 26 NSWLR 411 at 423; BC200402171 .

an order in the nature of prohibition does not lie to a person exercising the power of the court as its delegate: Tauhara Properties Ltd v Mercantile Developments Ltd [1974] 1 NZLR 584 at 592 ; but see R v Election Court; Ex parte Sheppard [1975] 2 All ER 723 at 725; [1975] 1 WLR 1319 at 1323 and Re Moresby North East Election Petition [1977] PNG LR 429 at 431. The appropriate procedure in such cases is to apply to a judge of the court for directions.

If the jurisdiction of a superior court depends upon the existence of a particular fact or event, mandamus or prohibition may lie if jurisdictional error is shown: R v Gray; Ex parte Marsh (1985) 157 CLR 351; 62 ALR 17; BC8501063 ; Re Gallagher; Ex parte Transport Workers' Union of Australia (1964) 65 SR (NSW) 309 at 314 ; R v Judges of the Federal Court of Australia; Ex parte Western Australian National Football League (Inc) (1979) 143 CLR 190 at 214–16; 23 ALR 439 ; DMW v CGW (1982) 151 CLR 491 at 507; 44 ALR 225; BC8200140 ; R v Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration; Ex parte Ozone Theatres (Aust) Ltd (1949) 78 CLR 389 at 399; [1949] ALR 675; BC4900150 ; R v Watson; Ex parte Armstrong (1976) 136 CLR 248 at 263; 9 ALR 551; BC7600059 ; Re Ross-Jones; Ex parte Green (1984) 156 CLR 185; 56 ALR 609; 59 ALJR 132; BC8400460 .

An order in the nature of prohibition should generally not be made unless the court to which the order is to be directed has had an opportunity to consider whether it has jurisdiction and has wrongly found that it has: R v Judges of the Federal Court of Australia; Ex parte Pilkington ACI (Operations) Pty Ltd (1978) 142 CLR 113 at 127; 23 ALR 69; BC7800090 ; cf R v Australian Stevedoring Industry Board; Ex parte Melbourne Stevedoring Co Pty Ltd (1953) 88 CLR 100 at 199; [1953] ALR 461; BC5300260 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 69.45] Inferior courts or tribunals — where internal appeals lie

heading.title: Inferior courts or tribunals — where internal appeals lie

p.text: Relief in the nature of the prerogative writs is not normally appropriate where there is an internal appeal procedure available within the court or tribunal in respect of which the relief is sought: Boral Gas (NSW) Pty Ltd v Magill (1993) 32 NSWLR 501 ; Ultra Tune (Aust) Pty Ltd v Swann (1983) AILR ¶250; (1984) 8 IR 122; Maltias v Industrial Commission of New South Wales (NSWCA, 22 April 1986, unreported); Algoni Pty Ltd v Retail Trade Industrial Tribunal (1987) 13 ALD 414; BC8701205 . And even where the inferior tribunal has made a jurisdictional error, that error will not necessarily void its decision so as to prevent an internal appeal process from being validly invoked: Calvin v Carr [1979] 1 NSWLR 1; (1979) 22 ALR 417 at 429 ; Twist v Randwick Municipal Council (1976) 136 CLR 106 at 116; 12 ALR 379 at 387 ; R v Marks; Ex parte Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation (1981) 147 CLR 471 at 485; 35 ALR 241 at 250 . But the principle (denying relief where an internal appeal process is available) is not inflexible: Hill v Green (1999) 48 NSWLR 161 at [151]–[164] , and much may depend on the scope and adequacy of the internal review procedure: Ackroyd v Whitehouse (1985) 2 NSWLR 239 at 248; or upon the nature of the issue involved and the likelihood of it being correctly determined in the subordinate tribunal: Weinel v Judge Parsons (1994) 62 SASR 501 ; New South Wales Breeding & Racing v Administrative Decisions Tribunal of New South Wales (2001) 53 NSWLR 559 (relief refused).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 69.50] Inferior courts or tribunals — restricted rights of appeal to the court

heading.title: Inferior courts or tribunals — restricted rights of appeal to the court

p.text: The court has a general supervisory role over all inferior courts and tribunals. The absence, or restricted nature, of a right of appeal does not prevent the court from granting relief in the nature of prerogative orders: Commissioner for Motor Transport v Kirkpatrick (1988) 13 NSWLR 368 (Transport Appeal Court — no right of appeal); Victims Compensation Fund Corp v GM (2004) 60 NSWLR 310; [2004] NSWCA 185; BC200403610 (no right of appeal). Thus, despite the restriction of rights of appeal from the District Court (the restriction is to judgments or orders "in an action") the Supreme Court can grant relief in the nature of certiorari for jurisdictional error, or error on the face of the record, in relation to District Court proceedings: Glenvill Homes Pty Ltd v Builders Licensing Board [1981] 2 NSWLR 608 (refusal to permit discovery in a statutory appeal); Adams v Kennick Trading (Int) Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 503; 10 ALN N47 (refusal to set aside default judgment); Keefe v Marks (1989) 16 NSWLR 713 ; Parker v DPP (1992) 28 NSWLR 282 (denial of procedural fairness when sentencing); Kopuz v District Court of New South Wales (1992) 28 NSWLR 232 (jurisdictional error).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 69.55] Prerogative orders in respect of proceedings where rights of appeal or review exist

heading.title: Prerogative orders in respect of proceedings where rights of appeal or review exist

p.text: Where the Supreme Court has both appellate and supervisory jurisdiction in respect of the same order, and the grounds for challenging that order would, if established, support the grant of either prerogative or appellate relief, it is for the court to decide the appropriate form of relief, even where jurisdictional error is alleged: Hill v King (1993) 31 NSWLR 654 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Farley (2001) 51 NSWLR 494; [2001] NSWSC 326; BC200101937 ; R v Justices of Surrey (1870) LR 5 QB 466; Worthington v Jeffries (1875) LR 10 CP 379. If a claim is made both by way of appeal and for prerogative relief, the claim should ordinarily be struck out as an abuse of process: Meagher v Stephenson (1993) 30 NSWLR 736 (appeal under the Liquor Act 1982 and a claim for prerogative relief); but compare Hargrave v Slater (2000) 113 A Crim R 371; [2000] NSWSC 387; BC200003031 at [3] .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 69.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 ss 66, 69.

Pursuant to SCA ss 66 and 69 , the court has jurisdiction to stay either in whole or in part the decision which it is sought to review, or to grant an appropriate injunction to hold the status quo pending the hearing of the appeal. That power extends to orders ancillary to the relief sought in the original proceedings. It is not confined to matters relating to the challenge to the jurisdiction exercised in those proceedings: Re Kerry [2010] NSWCA 232; BC201006589 at [23] per Young J (mandatory interim injunction granted ancillary relief sought under s 69 permitting supervised access order in respect of the care and control of a child).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 69A] s 69A Release on bail and custody of claimants seeking judicial review of conviction or sentence

leg:heading.title: Release on bail and custody of claimants seeking judicial review of conviction or sentence

p.text: This section and section 69B apply to proceedings in the Court by a convicted person (the claimant) seeking judicial review in relation to a conviction or sentence for an offence.

A claimant who is not released on bail must, pending the determination of the proceedings, be treated in such manner as may be directed by regulations made under the Crimes (Administration of Sentences) Act 1999 (which is referred to in this section as special treatment).
[subs (2) am Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4]
The time during which a claimant is at liberty on bail (pending the determination of the proceedings for review) does not count as part of any term of imprisonment under the claimant's sentence.
[subs (3) am Act 94 of 1999 s 6 and Sch 4]

The time during which an appellant receives special treatment counts as part of any term of imprisonment under the claimant's sentence. However, if the Court is satisfied that the claim was unarguable or frivolous, the Court may order that the time in custody with special treatment does not count.
[subs (4) am Act 94 of 1999 s 6 and Sch 4]
In determining proceedings for judicial review, the Court may order that the imprisonment under the original sentence of imprisonment is to commence or recommence on a day specified by the Court.
[subs (5) am Act 94 of 1999 s 6 and Sch 4]
the manner in which a claimant, when in custody, is to be brought to any place where the claimant is entitled to be present, or ordered to be taken, for the purposes of this Act, and
the manner in which the appellant is to be kept in custody whilst absent from prison for the purpose.
A claimant while in custody in accordance with those regulations is taken to be in legal custody.
[s 69A insrt Act 6 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 69B] s 69B Other powers in relation to claimants for judicial review of convictions and sentences

leg:heading.title: Other powers in relation to claimants for judicial review of convictions and sentences

p.text: In determining proceedings for judicial review in relation to a conviction or sentence for an offence, the Court may make an order quashing either the conviction of, or the sentence imposed on, the claimant, or quash both the conviction and the sentence.
This section applies to judicial review of orders made by the Local Court or the District Court despite anything contained in the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 .
[subs (2) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
[s 69B insrt Act 6 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 69C] s 69C Stay of execution of conviction, order or sentence pending review

leg:heading.title: Stay of execution of conviction, order or sentence pending review

p.text: This section and section 69D apply to proceedings in the Court for judicial review of a determination made by the District Court in appeal proceedings relating to a conviction or order made by the Local Court (or part of such a conviction or order) or sentence imposed by the Local Court.
[subs (1) Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
The execution of a sentence imposed as a consequence of a conviction, or of any other order, is stayed when proceedings seeking judicial review are commenced.

Subsection (2) does not apply to a person (the claimant) who is in custody when proceedings seeking judicial review are commenced unless and until the claimant enters into a bail undertaking in accordance with the Bail Act 1978, or bail is dispensed with.
The stay of execution continues until the proceedings for judicial review are finally determined, subject to any order or direction of the Court.

Despite subsection (2), any period during which the stay is in force is not to be taken into account when calculating the length of a period of disqualification from holding a driver licence resulting from a conviction under the road transport legislation within the meaning of the Road Transport (General) Act 2005.
[subs (5) am Act 11 of 2005 Sch 3.42, effective 30 September 2005]
[s 69C insrt Act 137 of 1998 s 4 and Sch 2 ; am Act 19 of 1999 s 4 and Sch 2 ; Act 53 of 2000 Sch 3 ; Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 69D] s 69D Court may confirm conviction or order with effect from an earlier day

leg:heading.title: Court may confirm conviction or order with effect from an earlier day

p.text: The Supreme Court may order that a conviction, order or sentence that is the subject of proceedings, or any part of it:
is to take effect on and from a day specified in the order, or
in the case of a sentence that has been served in part, is to recommence on and from a day specified in the order,
being the day the order is made or an earlier day.
The order has effect even though a stay of execution may have been in force in respect of the sentence that is the subject of the proceedings.
[s 69D insrt Act 137 of 1998 s 4 and Sch 2]

Where any person acts in an office in which the person is not entitled to act and an information in the nature of quo warranto would, but for section 12 , lie against the person, the Court may grant an injunction restraining the person from so acting and may (if the case so requires) declare the office to be vacant.
[ s 70 am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 70.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.18, r 45.3.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 70.10] The nature of quo warranto

p.text: “An information in the nature of a quo warranto ... lay against a person who claimed or usurped an office, franchise, or liberty, to enquire by what authority he or she supported his or her claim, in order that the right to the office or franchise might be determined. It also lay in cases of non-user abuse, or non neglect of a franchise”: Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 1, para 169. A scope of the remedy is further discussed in R v Speyer [1916] 1 KB 595 at 608–9 (affirmed on other grounds [1916] 2 KB 858) (a question as to whether a naturalised person could be a Privy Councillor) and Darley v R (1846) 12 Cl & Fin 520; 8 ER 1513 and Liston v Davies (1937) 57 CLR 424 at 431; [1937] ALR 305 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 70.15] Examples of the use of quo warranto

heading.title: Examples of the use of quo warranto

p.text: Quo warranto has been used in Australia to challenge the dismissal of a council (though the court discharged an order nisi without pronouncing on the jurisdictional question) (R v Barnett; Ex parte Warringah Shire Council [1967] NSWR 746; (1967) 70 SR (NSW) 69 ), the validity of the appointment of a judge of the Commonwealth Court of Industrial Arbitration (McCawley v R (1918) 26 CLR 9; 24 ALR 413 ; McCawley v R (1920) 28 CLR 106; 26 ALR 286 ) and the holding of office of aldermen on a council: Liston v Davies (1937) 57 CLR 424; [1937] ALR 305 .

It is an open question as to who can apply under this section for an order in lieu of quo warranto. Under the old law, it would appear that anybody could approach the court to issue an order nisi for quo warranto. The court would consider whether it felt the applicant had sufficient interest and what his or her motives were before issuing an order nisi, though it was quite clear that by at least the early part of the 20th century, it was not necessary to approach the Attorney-General to apply for quo warranto by means of a relator suit in the usual sense. See R v Speyer [1916] 1 KB 595; Liston v Davies (1937) 57 CLR 424; [1937] ALR 305 and Serbian Orthodox Ecclesiastical School Community v Vlaislavljevic [1970] Qd R 386 at 393 .

It is well accepted that the court will not permit discovery and interrogatories in proceedings to recover a penalty or to enforce a forfeiture: Earl of Mexborough v Whitwood Urban District Council [1897] 2 QB 111; Martin v Treacher (1880) 16 QBD 507; Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328; 45 ALR 609 . There is an analogy between such proceedings and proceedings for an injunction or declaration under this section. The result is that it will ordinarily be inappropriate to order a defendant to provide discovery or to answer interrogatories. This is so notwithstanding statements to the contrary effect in Bray's, Principles and Practice of Discovery, and the authorities referred to therein: Taylor v Carmichael [1984] 1 NSWLR 421.
The Court may, on an application for a writ of habeas corpus, give such judgment or make such order disposing of the proceedings as the nature of the case requires.
[subs (1) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]

Where an application for a writ of habeas corpus has been made in respect of any person, no application for a writ of habeas corpus shall again be made in respect of that person on the same grounds, whether to the same Judge or to any other Judge or to the Court of Appeal, unless fresh evidence is adduced in support of the application.
Subsection (2) applies notwithstanding anything in any Act or rule of law.
Subject to the rules, a writ of habeas corpus may be enforced in the ways in which a judgment or order of the Court may be enforced.
[subs (3A) insrt Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
Subsection (3A) does not affect the power of the Court to punish for contempt.
[subs (3B) insrt Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
In this section, writ of habeas corpus means a writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 69(1)(d).
