Historically there were five different types of writs of habeas corpus of which habeas corpus ad subjiciendum referred to in the section was the most common. The combined effect of s 69(1)(d) and the present section is that the court can only issue the writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum (although this limitation does not limit the court's substantive power to grant appropriate relief). The writ of habeas corpus is used to secure the liberty of a person improperly detained as well as to enable a person having legal custody of a minor to obtain the child himself or herself. An appropriate form of writ is prescribed in SCR Sch F Form 71.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 Section 69(1)(d).

Formerly the usual procedure was to file a summons for the defendant to show cause why a writ of habeas corpus should not issue. The “show cause” procedure was adopted for the sake of convenience (Re Greig and Heriot [1944] VLR 66 at 70 ), and avoided the necessity of producing the person concerned at the hearing: Re Egginton (1853) 2 El & Bl 717; 118 ER 936. Nevertheless, the writ itself would issue immediately if it was likely that notice of the application might result in a person concerned being removed from the jurisdiction: Ex parte Witte (1853) 13 CB 680; 138 ER 1367. Section 69(1)(d) effectively abolished the “show cause” procedure.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.4(2)(a).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.2(1)(a).

Proceedings are commenced by summons with a supporting affidavit: UCPR r 6.4(2)(a) . In an urgent case an affidavit alone is sufficient: UCPR r 25.2(1)(a) . Unless the application is actually made by the prisoner, the evidence must show either that the prisoner consents to the application or that the circumstances of the imprisonment prevent consent being obtained: Re Parker, Canadian Prisoners Case (1839) 5 M & W 32; 141 ER 15; Re Corke [1954] 2 All ER 440; [1954] 1 WLR 899 ; Re Winara Parata [1878–80] 1 OB & F (SC) 31 (NZ). The affidavit should set out all the material facts and show circumstances disclosing a prima facie case for the issue of the writ. For example, the evidence must tend to show that the person has been involuntarily detained: R v Wiseman; Ex parte Newton (1895) 2 Smith KB 617 (husband seeking habeas corpus, against a third person, in relation to his own wife).

An order cannot be made in respect of a non-resident: Re Brown v Kalal (1986) 7 NSWLR 423. It is uncertain whether a writ of habeas corpus has operation outside the state: A v B [1979] 1 NSWLR 57; (1979) 4 Fam LR 748 distinguishing Glasson v Scott [1973] 1 NSWLR 689.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 71(2).

There is a right of appeal against an order made under this section: Ex parte Sampson: Re Governor of HM Penitentiary at Malabar (1965) 66 SR (NSW) 501. If, on the other hand, the application for an order is refused, a further application (not an appeal) may be made, including an application to the Court of Appeal but fresh evidence must be adduced: s 71(2) . Without this restriction it was possible under the previous show cause procedure for a disappointed applicant to renew the application before another judge of the court: Ex parte Rowlands (1895) 16 LR (NSW) 239 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.19(a).
(CTH) Family Law Act 1975.

Proceedings for habeas corpus in respect of a minor are assigned to the Equity Division (UCPR r 1.19(a) ). There is no jurisdiction to make any order for habeas corpus where custody of a child is sought and the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) applies: Clarke v McInness [1978] 1 NSWLR 598.

Unless it is a consequence of a conviction by a court, the defendant bears the onus of justifying the legality of the detention: Sharpe, Sharpe on Habeas Corpus, Oxford, 1976, p 81; R v Governor of Brixton Prison; Ex parte Ahsan [1969] 2 QB 222; R v Governor of Metropolitan Gaol [1963] VR 61 at 62 . See also R v Governor of Brixton Prison; Ex parte Guerin (1907) 51 Sol Jo 571 and cf Guerin v Bank of France (1888) 5 TLR 160. If proper grounds are made out for habeas corpus, the court has no discretion to refuse relief: Azam v Home Secretary [1974] AC 18 at 41–2 ; Sharpe, above, p 56. Generally, as to habeas corpus see Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, re-issue, Vol 1(1), paras 222–65; Bedgood v Keeper of Her Majesty's Penitentiary at Malabar [1975] 2 NSWLR 144.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 71.40] Such order as the nature of the case requires

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 71.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 71(1).

heading.title: Such order as the nature of the case requires

p.text: The power granted in s 71(1) is wide enough to allow an order requiring the return of a prisoner to a gaol from which he or she has been transferred without lawful authority: Kelleher v Corrective Services Commission of New South Wales (1987) 8 NSWLR 423.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 71A] s 71A Powers of Court in relation to warrants in respect of convictions or orders of Local Court

leg:heading.title: Powers of Court in relation to warrants in respect of convictions or orders of Local Court

p.text: In this section, warrant means a warrant of commitment issued in relation to a conviction or order of the Local Court.
[subs (1) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
This section has effect despite section 71.

In proceedings for a writ of habeas corpus or for the setting aside of a conviction or order of the Local Court, the Supreme Court is not to make an order for the discharge from custody of a person in custody under a warrant on the ground of any defect or error in the warrant unless the requirements of subsection (4) have been complied with.
[subs (3) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
The requirements are that the Magistrate, prosecutor or party interested in supporting the warrant:
has had notice of intention to apply for the order, and
has been required to transmit, or has had the opportunity to transmit, to the Supreme Court the following documents, or certified copies of them:
the conviction or order, and
the information (if any) and transcript of evidence intended to be relied on in support of the conviction or order.
Subject to the rules, the notice of intention to apply for the order may be given at any stage of proceedings in the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court may dispense with the notice if copies of the conviction or order and of the transcript of evidence are produced to the Court.
The Supreme Court is to allow the warrant and the conviction or order if necessary to be amended if:
the conviction or order and transcript of evidence have been transmitted to the Supreme Court in accordance with this section, and
the offence or matter charged or intended to have been charged appears to have been established, and
the judgment of the Local Court appears to have been warranted in substance.
After any such amendment:
the person committed is to be remanded to the person's former custody or the conviction or order may be enforced in the proper manner, and
the conviction or order is to be treated as if it had originally stood so amended.
This section does not apply to an order of the Supreme Court under Part 5 of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001.
[subs (9) am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]
[s 71A insrt Act 137 of 1998 s 4 and Sch 2.24]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 71B] s 71B Person to be remanded to former custody

leg:heading.title: Person to be remanded to former custody

p.text: The Supreme Court may remand a person who has been committed to prison by virtue of any summary conviction or order of the Local Court and has been brought up by a writ of habeas corpus to the person's former custody to serve the rest of the term for which the person was committed if the judgment of the Supreme Court is against the person.
[s 71B insrt Act 137 of 1998 s 4 and Sch 2.24 ; am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 72] s 72 Production of person confined

p.text: In this section “tribunal or authority” means any court, judge or other judicature, or any referee, arbitrator or umpire, or any person authorised to take the examination of any witness or to conduct any inquiry, whether so authorised for the purpose of proceedings in the Court or for any other purpose.

ci:cite.ci:content: 16 and 17 Vict c 30 s 9; Act 29 of 1902 s 18(2); Act 30 of 1969 s 42

p.text: [subs (1) am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]

Where any prisoner or person is confined in any prison or place, under any sentence or under commitment for trial or otherwise, the Court may make orders for bringing the prisoner or person before any tribunal or authority, for the purpose of answering any charge or otherwise taking part in any proceedings or matter before the tribunal or authority, or for the purpose of being examined as a witness, and for returning the prisoner or person to confinement.
[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
[ s 72 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 7]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 72.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Correctional Centres Act 1952 s 44.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 s 565.

This section provides a relatively quick method of obtaining the attendance of a prisoner to give evidence. It is to be used in preference to the procedure under s 44 of the Prisons Act 1952. The present section arguably has a wider application than both that provision and also s 565 of the Crimes Act 1900.

In proceedings for a forfeiture for non-payment of rent, the Court may, on terms, give relief and, if the lessee is so relieved, he or she shall hold the demised premises according to the terms of the lease, and without the necessity of any new lease.
[s 73 am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

Before the Act came into force the equitable jurisdiction of the court would, in the appropriate case, give relief against forfeiture to tenants where they confessed their default and offered amends. The jurisdiction was and is not limited to cases of non-payment of rent. If the lease had not been determined, the order of the court kept the former lease alive; if it had been properly determined, a new lease for the balance of the term came into existence. This jurisdiction was available notwithstanding that the lease had been deregistered from the Torrens Title Register: Brooker's Colours Ltd v Sproules (1910) 10 SR (NSW) 839 . For a full treatment of relief from forfeiture see Brooking and Chernov, Tenancy Law and Practice Victoria, 1980, 2nd ed, 238 et seq.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 73.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Landlord and Tenant Act 1899 s 10.
At common law before the Act, if an action in ejectment was commenced it was permanently stayed if the arrears of rent and costs were paid into court ( s 10 of Landlord and Tenant Act 1899).

This section does not affect the general powers of the court to relieve against forfeiture, but deals with a particular situation, that is, relief against non-payment of rent. In such a situation except in special circumstances the order of the court under this section will be that relief will be given if all the rent and costs have been tendered: Gill v Lewis [1956] 2 QB 1. However there will be special circumstances if the evidence discloses that the tenant would not be able to pay future rent or that such payments may constitute a preference: Direct Food Supplies (Vic) Pty Ltd v DLV Pty Ltd [1975] VR 358 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 73.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Landlord and Tenant Act 1899 s 8.

Under Landlord and Tenant Act 1899 s 8 as amended by the schedules to the Supreme Court Act (see Second Sch) relief against forfeiture can only be sought up to a date six months after execution of a judgment for possession. The former s 10 also remains in force in an amended form.

Where the court grants relief on terms to be followed within a certain time, then, semble, the court may grant an extension of time even though the original order did not expressly reserve “liberty to apply”: Chandless-Chandless v Nicholson [1942] 2 KB 321.

The court grants relief against forfeiture where justice requires and on equitable terms: Starside Properties Ltd v Mustapha [1974] 2 All ER 567; [1974] 1 WLR 816 and see Chandless-Chandless v Nicholson [1942] 2 KB 321 and Gill v Lewis [1956] 2 QB 1. For NSW authorities see Langley v Foster (1909) 10 SR (NSW) 54 and the decision of Hope J in Pioneer Quarries (Sydney) Pty Ltd v Permanent Trustee Co of New South Wales Ltd (1970) 2 BPR 9562; Stieper v Deviot Pty Ltd (1977) 2 BPR 9602.
